title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: Why did the hard drive feel colder than the book, despite being at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: The hard drive was made of a material with lower thermal conductivity.

options.label: B
options.text: The hard drive was conducting heat away from the hand faster than the book.

options.label: C
options.text: The hard drive was exposed to a colder environment than the book.

options.label: D
options.text: The hard drive had a different shape than the book.

options.label: B
options.text: Distance between objects.

options.label: C
options.text: Humidity in the air.

options.label: D
options.text: Light intensity.

options.label: A
options.text: Because aluminium is a worse conductor of heat than plastic.

options.label: B
options.text: Because aluminium has lower thermal conductivity than plastic.

options.label: C
options.text: Because aluminium has higher thermal conductivity than plastic.

options.label: D
options.text: Because plastic is a better conductor of heat than aluminium.

options.label: A
options.text: Thermal conductivity.

options.label: B
options.text: Thermoconduction.

options.label: C
options.text: Heat transfer rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Thermoconductivity.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the bath mat feel warmer than the towel when standing on it after a shower?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is made of a warmer material than the towel.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat is a better insulator than the towel.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the bath mat is exposed to a warmer environment than the towel.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat away from the body more slowly than the towel.

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the difference in temperature between the two blocks.

options.label: B
options.text: To show the effect of heat transfer on the melting of the ice cube.

options.label: C
options.text: To compare the thermal conductivity of the two blocks.

options.label: D
options.text: To measure the distance between the two blocks.

options.label: A
options.text: You feel the temperature of the object.

options.label: B
options.text: You feel the rate at which heat is conducted away from or towards you.

options.label: C
options.text: You feel the shape of the object.

options.label: D
options.text: You feel the weight of the object.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between thermal conductivity and the sensation of warmth or cold?

options.label: A
options.text: Higher thermal conductivity makes an object feel warmer.

options.label: B
options.text: Lower thermal conductivity makes an object feel colder.

options.label: C
options.text: Higher thermal conductivity makes an object feel colder.

options.label: D
options.text: Lower thermal conductivity makes an object feel warmer.

options.label: A
options.text: Because metal is a worse conductor of heat than other materials.

options.label: B
options.text: Because metal has lower thermal conductivity than other materials.

options.label: C
options.text: Because metal has higher thermal conductivity than other materials.

options.label: D
options.text: Because metal is a better insulator than other materials.

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the difference in temperature between the two materials.

options.label: B
options.text: To show the effect of heat transfer on the sensation of warmth.

options.label: C
options.text: To compare the thermal conductivity of the two materials.

options.label: D

title: Can You Solve This?

options.text: To identify a pattern in a sequence of numbers

options.text: To figure out a rule that governs a sequence of numbers

options.text: Numbers in decreasing order

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Add 2 to the previous number

options.label: D
options.text: Numbers in increasing order

options.label: A
options.text: A theory that is always true

options.label: B
options.text: A common and predictable event

options.label: C
options.text: A rare and unusual event that challenges existing theories

options.label: D
options.text: A theory that is never true

multiple-choice.question: According to the video, what is the significance of getting "no" answers in the scientific method?

options.label: A
options.text: It confirms our theories

options.label: B
options.text: It disproves our theories and provides no further information

options.label: C
options.text: It provides more information than "yes" answers and helps to refine our theories

options.label: D
options.text: It is not important

multiple-choice.question: How should one approach a problem or theory to get to the truth, according to the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to confirm what you believe by seeking "yes" answers

options.label: B
options.text: Try to disprove what you believe by seeking "no" answers

options.label: C
options.text: Seek information from others without questioning your own theories

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore the problem or theory

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the scientific method, as discussed in the video?

options.label: A
options.text: To prove our theories true by seeking "yes" answers

options.label: B
options.text: To disprove our theories and find the truth by seeking "no" answers

options.label: C
options.text: To gather information from others without questioning our own theories

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore our theories and rely on intuition

multiple-choice.question: Where did the author of the video get the idea for the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: From a book on statistics

options.label: B
options.text: From a book on the scientific method

options.label: C
options.text: From a book called "The Black Swan" by Nassim Taleb

options.label: D
options.text: From a personal experience

multiple-choice.question: What can be learned from the participants' initial approach to the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: That they should have sought more information from the author

options.label: B
options.text: That they should have tried to disprove their theories from the start

options.label: C
options.text: That they were too focused on confirming their own theories

options.label: D
options.text: That they should have ignored the problem

multiple-choice.question: How does the scientific method relate to the idea of getting "no" answers?

options.label: A
options.text: The scientific method seeks to confirm theories with "yes" answers

options.label: B
options.text: The scientific method seeks to disprove theories with "no" answers

options.label: C
options.text: The scientific method ignores "no" answers and relies on intuition

options.label: D
options.text: The scientific method is unrelated to the idea of getting "no" answers

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the video, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: To always seek information from others without questioning your own theories

options.label: B
options.text: To try to confirm what you believe by seeking "yes" answers

options.label: C
options.text: To try to disprove what you believe and find the truth by seeking "no" answers

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore your theories and rely on intuition

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What percentage of the world's population is estimated to have been destroyed by the Black Death?
**Comprehension**: How did the spread of the Black Death differ from modern instances of plague, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The Black Death spread faster and was more deadly due to direct human-to-human transmission.

options.label: B
options.text: The Black Death spread slower and was less deadly due to rodent fleas.

options.label: C
options.text: The Black Death was caused by a different pathogen.

options.label: D
options.text: The Black Death had the same transmission method as modern plague.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: If a similar pandemic were to occur today, what would likely be the most significant impact on society?

options.label: A
options.text: Economic collapse and widespread famine.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased social mobility and political reforms.

options.label: C
options.text: A significant decrease in living standards and a rise in poverty.

options.label: D
options.text: A strain on healthcare systems and potential shortages of essential goods.

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: What was the main reason for the high mortality rate of the Black Death in Europe during the 14th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease itself was highly contagious and deadly.

options.label: B
options.text: The population was already weakened by poverty, poor health, and malnutrition.

options.label: C
options.text: The climate was particularly harsh during that time.

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of medical care and antibiotics.

options.label: A
options.text: They could lead to a decrease in the population's immune system.

options.label: B
options.text: They could lead to an increase in the population's resistance to diseases.

options.label: C
options.text: They could have no impact on modern society.

options.label: D
options.text: They could lead to new treatments and vaccines for diseases.

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it could lead to the development of new treatments and vaccines.

options.label: B
options.text: No, it is not relevant to modern society.

options.label: C
options.text: Maybe, it could have some benefits but also some drawbacks.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too early to tell.

options.label: B
options.text: The Black Death

options.label: C
options.text: The Bubonic Plague

options.label: D
options.text: The Medieval Plague

options.text: The rapid loss of population led to a decrease in the demand for labor.

options.label: B
options.text: The increase in food availability led to higher wages and better living standards.

options.label: C
options.text: The decrease in the population led to a decrease in the number of people competing for jobs.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The climate was warm, leading to an increase in population growth.

options.label: C
options.text: The climate had no impact on population growth.

options.label: D
options.text: The climate was variable, leading to fluctuations in population growth.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain is prioritizing edge detection in other areas

options.label: D
options.text: Because the eyes are not adapted to see complex patterns

multiple-choice.question: What assumption does the brain's visual cortex make about the lighting of an image, as demonstrated by the muffin pan example?

options.label: A
options.text: That light comes from multiple sources

options.label: B
options.text: That light comes from a single source, shining down from above

options.label: C
options.text: That light is evenly distributed across the image

options.label: D
options.text: That light is not an important factor in image interpretation

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the image of Abraham Lincoln is flipped upside down and then right side up again?

options.label: A
options.text: The face appears distorted due to the brain's expectations

options.label: B
options.text: The face appears normal because the brain adjusts its expectations

options.label: C
options.text: The face is no longer recognizable due to the change in orientation

options.label: D
options.text: The face appears upside down due to a lack of adjustment

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain's visual cortex operate on assumptions about the lighting of an image?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce cognitive load and increase efficiency

options.label: B
options.text: To increase accuracy by considering multiple possibilities

options.label: C
options.text: To prioritize edge detection over other visual information

options.label: D
options.text: To compensate for limited visual information by making random guesses

multiple-choice.question: What does the example of the upside-down Lincoln face reveal about the brain's visual system?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is inefficient and relies on random guesses

options.label: B
options.text: That it is efficient and uses assumptions to create a tailored vision of the world

options.label: C
options.text: That it is not adapted to see faces in unusual orientations

options.label: D
options.text: That it is not able to recognize patterns in complex images

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of the brain's visual system, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a 2D image of the world by combining visual information

options.label: B
options.text: To recognize faces and objects using prior knowledge and expectations

options.label: C
options.text: To allocate cognitive energy and construct a world on the fly using efficient assumptions

options.label: D
options.text: To prioritize edge detection and ignore other visual information

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of lateral inhibition in the brain's visual system?

options.label: A
options.text: To decrease contrast with surrounding areas and reduce visual noise

options.label: B
options.text: To increase contrast with surrounding areas and enhance edge detection

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore surrounding areas and focus on a single point

options.label: D
options.text: To average the brightness of surrounding areas and reduce differences

multiple-choice.question: What does the example of the grid with the white spot at the center reveal about the brain's visual system?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is inefficient and relies on random guesses

options.label: B
options.text: That it is efficient and uses assumptions to create a tailored vision of the world

options.label: C
options.text: That it is not adapted to see edges in complex patterns

options.label: D
options.text: That it is not able to recognize patterns in simple images

multiple-choice.question: Why is the brain's visual system able to create a 3D image of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it uses prior knowledge and expectations to fill in gaps

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is efficient and uses assumptions to create a tailored vision of the world

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is not limited by the quality of visual information and can always see everything

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is able to recognize patterns and edges in 2D images

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth's surface is comprised of coral reefs, which are home to a significant portion of the 27,000 known fish species?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 0.1%

options.label: B
options.text: Less than 1%

options.label: C
options.text: Approximately 5%

options.label: D
options.text: Approximately 10%

multiple-choice.question: How do most coral reef fish parents reproduce?

options.label: A
options.text: By laying eggs in a nest

options.label: B
options.text: By giving birth to live young

options.label: C
options.text: By releasing sperm and eggs into the water column

options.label: D
options.text: By internal fertilization

multiple-choice.question: What is a distinctive feature of the skin of newly hatched coral reef fish larvae?

options.label: A
options.text: It is very thick and protective

options.label: B
options.text: It is covered in scales

options.label: C
options.text: It is tissue-thin and absorbs oxygen directly from the water

options.label: D
options.text: It has a unique pattern of coloration

multiple-choice.question: According to recent research, what sensory systems do coral reef fish larvae use to navigate to their preferred adult habitats?

options.label: A
options.text: Magnetic fields and visual cues

options.label: B
options.text: Sound and magnetic fields

options.label: C
options.text: Sound and smell

options.label: D
options.text: Water temperature and salinity

multiple-choice.question: What strategy do coral reef fish larvae use when searching for a suitable reef to settle on, allowing them to assess the reef before committing to it?

options.label: A
options.text: They jump from the water column and try to land on the reef

options.label: B
options.text: They drop down to check out a reef and can jump back up if conditions aren't right

options.label: C
options.text: They use a network of underwater currents to travel between reefs

options.label: D
options.text: They follow a specific migration route

multiple-choice.question: What aspect of coral reef fish larvae is currently not well understood?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to swim

options.label: B
options.text: Their sensory systems

options.label: C
options.text: The geographic movements of individual larvae for most species

options.label: D
